instruction:
Please proofread and polish the passage from an academic angle and highlight the modification:
The purpose of this research was to detect the changes of happiness, the ultimate pursuit of human being, in China, by examing happines inside Chinese brain (i.e., lay beleifs) and outside Chinese brain (i.e., natural languages). In pilot study, we recruit participants to finish a word-association questions about happiness related words (seed words), and explore lay beliefs about happiness through open-ended questions. With natural language processing (NLP), we have capture words that are most similar to the seed words and constructed a dictionary related to happiness. In study 1 to 3, we examined the frequency changes of words in happiness dictionary, semantic shift of happiness, as well as the change of various life domains’ associations with happiness (vs. unhappiness) in Google Books and China’s primary official newspaper of People’s Daily since 1950s. Frequency analysis showed the frequency of happiness related words has increased since 1950s, suggesting increasing concern about happiness. Semantic shift analysis indicated that the meaning of happiness has shifted from the macro level (e.g., collective events) to the micro level (e.g., individual experiences). Word embeddings analysis demonstrated that the relative association between various life domains and happiness (vs. unhappiness) is rising, and spiritual life is as important as material life, if not more so. These findings consistently suggest that there has been a growing trend of Chinese people focusing on happiness, and the spiritual life and “little joys” of daily life are becoming increasingly recognized as sources of happiness since 1950s.
output: The purpose of this research was to detect the changes of happiness, the ultimate pursuit of human beings, in China by examining happiness inside Chinese brain (i.e., lay beliefs) and outside Chinese brain (i.e., natural languages). In a pilot study, we recruited participants to finish a word-association task about happiness related words (seed words), and explore lay beliefs about happiness through open-ended questions. With natural language processing (NLP), we have captured words that are most similar to the seed words and constructed a dictionary related to happiness. In Study 1 to 3, we examined the frequency changes of words in the happiness dictionary, semantic shift of happiness, as well as the changes of various life domains’ associations with happiness (versus unhappiness) in Google Books and China's primary official newspaper of People's Daily since the 1950s. Frequency analysis showed the frequency of happiness related words has increased since the 1950s, suggesting increasing concern about happiness. Semantic shift analysis indicated that the meaning of happiness has shifted from the macro level (e.g., collective events) to the micro level (e.g., individual experiences). Word embeddings analysis demonstrated that the relative association between various life domains and happiness (versus unhappiness) is rising, and spiritual life is as important as material life, if not more so. These findings consistently suggest that there has been a growing trend of Chinese people focusing on happiness, and the spiritual life and "little joys" of daily life are becoming increasingly recognized as sources of happiness since the 1950s. .

instruction: Why can't bank use cash as capital as a buffer for potential losses?
output:
I think this would be a good idea. If my bank has $1000 in cash and the FDIC guarantees deposits up to $250,000 then if the bank goes under I will only lose the first $1000 as opposed to potentially losing all of it.
If they can't use cash as capital then what is?
united-states banking fdic capital
Banknotes are in fact currency (deposits). – Dunk Jul 3 '12 at 22:46
Also, the FDIC itself is funded by assessments on deposit insurance premiums paid by banks - i.e., banks pay into the FDIC from which money is then used to pay off depositors whose funds are insured. – JoeTaxpayer♦ Jul 3 '12 at 22:47
The FDIC is funded through premiums that banks pay. – JoeTaxpayer♦ Jul 3 '12 at 23:21
A bank could hold cash as an asset, but not as "capital". Capital is defined as equity + reserves (including retained earnings). Cash isn't considered equity (and shouldn't be, since there's no reason to treat cash differently than any other asset). Thus, you can't count cash as capital. However, the FDIC insurance fund is actually funded by member banks, so in practice they do pay into an insurance fund that covers deposits.
Not the answer you're looking for? Browse other questions tagged united-states banking fdic capital or ask your own question.
Are the assets of commercial banks really “assets”?

instruction: convert December 21 · 1:00 – 1:50pm pacific to asia/taipei time
output:
Convert December 21, 1:00 – 1:50pm Pacific Time to Asia/Taipei Time
To convert Pacific Standard Time (PST) to Asia/Taipei Time (CLT), you have to take into account that Pacific Standard Time is one of the seven zones of the UTC-8 timezone and Asia/Taipei Time is also one of the seventeen zones of the UTC+08 timezone. The time zone offset for Pacific Standard Time is -08:00, while the time zone offset for Asia/Taipei Time is +08:00. So, subtracting nine hours from Pacific Standard Time will give you Asia/Taipei Time.
Fortunately, there are several simple ways to convert December 21, 1:00 – 1:50pm Pacific Time to Asia/Taipei Time. You can use a calculator, an online converter, or even figure it out by hand with a few basic math operations.

instruction:
rank the following companies by how pro-consumer they are:
Microsoft, Google, Nintendo, Sony, EA.
output:
I think it would be quite a while before EA is considered pro-consumer. I could see them taking the lead in some areas, but I doubt they'll be at the top any time soon.
I'd rank them as follows:
1) Google (for now, at least) - They are doing their best to make Android an open platform and push OEMs to support it. They are also doing things like Chromebooks, which can actually help low income consumers.
2) Microsoft - While their policies towards their own ecosystem aren't always great, they have been working on making Xbox more accessible to everyone including those who can't afford it. They have also been increasingly embracing cross-platform play and have been improving the Xbox app for Windows 10.
3) Nintendo - Because of their current success with the Switch (which is a heck of a lot more consumer friendly than the Wii U), but if we consider their history, Nintendo has always been a company that is very protective of the consumer's experience.
4) Sony - There is a reason why their consoles are so expensive, they don't need to discount them or embark on sales like the competition does. It's because they know their products are high quality and will sell regardless of price. Also, PS Now is a nice way for consumers to get access to older games without having to buy an entire console just for 1 or 2 games.
5) EA - While they aren't the worst publisher out there, they clearly prioritize profit over everything else. A good example of that is how Origin works. They lock their PC gamers into their platform even when other digital distributors are providing better prices for the same games.
It should be noted that all of these companies have made moves in the right direction or have shown

instruction: Create an Annotated Bibliography, in APA citation style, with six entries describing a different social media technology in each of the following six categories: blogs, social networking sites, virtual social worlds, virtual game worlds, collaborative projects, content communities.

varieties of virtual worlds that could be used in educational settings.
For each of the six categories, choose a different social media technology and provide a brief description of the technology, including its purpose, intended audience, and any relevant research or evaluation findings (if available).
Blogs: Blogs are web-based publications that are typically maintained by an individual or a small group of authors. They are often used as a platform for sharing personal thoughts, opinions, and experiences, or as a way to discuss a particular topic or issue.
Example: The Huffington Post is a blogging site that covers a wide range of topics, from politics and current affairs to entertainment and lifestyle. It has a large audience and is known for its opinion pieces and original content.
Social Networking Sites: Social networking sites are online platforms that allow users to connect with others, share information, and build relationships. They are often used for socializing, professional networking, and collaboration.
Example: Facebook is a popular social networking site that allows users to connect with friends, family, and colleagues. It also offers features such as groups, events, and pages for businesses and organizations.
Virtual Social Worlds: Virtual social worlds are immersive 3D environments that allow users to socialize, play games, and participate in other activities. They are often designed to simulate real-world environments and interactions.
Example: Second Life is a virtual social world that allows users to create avatars and explore a virtual world filled with shops, events, and other activities. It has been used in educational settings for training, simulation, and role-playing.
Virtual Game Worlds: Virtual game worlds are online games that allow users to interact with others and engage in simulated activities. They are often designed to be highly immersive and realistic.
Example: World of Warcraft is a popular virtual game world

instruction:
Mill vs Gartner
This case is about a dispute over the right to dig clay on a piece of land. The plaintiffs argued that the defendant, Allen, had only a verbal agreement, or a "parol license," to enter the land and take clay. The defendant claimed that he had an actual leasehold interest in the land, which entitled him to dig clay. The court found that the defendant's defense was sufficient, as it constituted a lease of the land for the purpose of taking clay. The court also found that the defendant's offer of testimony was admissible, and that the testimony was sufficient to submit to the jury. The court concluded that the trial judge had properly ruled on the case and that the judgment should be affirmed.

Smith vs Mill Company
The case is about the interpretation of a clause in a lease agreement between the lessors and lessees regarding the payment of taxes on coal in the ground. The clause in question stated that the lessors must pay all taxes imposed on the coal in the ground. The court held that the meaning of the clause was clear and plain, and that it was an absolute obligation on the part of the lessors to pay the taxes. The court also considered the effect of deeds of conveyance made after the lease agreement and concluded that they did not change the rights of the parties under the lease agreement. The court further held that the lessees still had the exclusive privilege to take the coal and were subject to the same duties as under the lease agreement, and the lessors still held all the beneficial interests that they held under the lease agreement. The court concluded that the positive agreement of the lessors to pay the taxes was not dependent on any technical aspect of their interest in the coal and was absolute, peremptory, and without condition.

Gartner vs Baker
The case of "Opinion, Min Justice Mitchell" was an ejectment lawsuit brought by plaintiffs against defendants who claimed to hold possession of the plaintiffs' land as lessees. The case revolved around a lease agreement made in 1864 between the plaintiffs (who were minors at the time and represented by their guardians) and the defendants, who were lessees of the land. The lease was made with the approval of a special act of assembly. The defendants claimed that the title was res adjudicata and the judge at the trial agreed, except for the continuance of the lease beyond twenty years, which he held to still be in force as a matter of law. The remaining specifications of error raised four questions, including the constitutionality of the act of assembly, the execution of the lease in accordance with the act, the validity of the lease, and whether it had expired by its own terms. These questions were resolved in favor of the defendants and the decree was affirmed by the court in a brief per curiam opinion, referring to the absence of fraud.

Which of these cases are a good fit for "Find me cases where the dispute involved involve mine leases."? Include a summary for each.
output:
Mill vs Gartner
This case is a good fit for "Find me cases where the dispute involved mine leases." The dispute in this case was over a lease agreement for land to dig clay.

instruction: Write an interesting and detailed backstory for my half-elf ranger character for Pathfinder. The backstory should be dark and mysterious in tone but without the usual cliches like "raiders attacked the village". Make it unique and interesting. Be creative.
output: Your character is a half-elf ranger with a mysterious past. They were born in the small village of Woodhaven, but their parents were killed by a group of orcs when they were just a child. The orcs left the child for dead, but they were found and taken in by a group of rangers who trained them to be a skilled hunter and survivalist. They eventually left the group to become a ranger themselves, but not before swearing vengeance on the orcs that took everything from them. Your character has spent the last few years tracking down the orcs responsible for the destruction of their home and has finally found them in the mountains north of the village. They are now ready to exact their revenge and put an end to the orcish threat once and for all.

instruction:
Hey GPT-3 here is a prompt for you:

Goal: To create a resort scavenger hunt for teams of employees of a big company, taking place at the Royal Livingstone Victoria Falls Zambia Hotel by Anantara. The event should last approximately two hours, with 10 missions that are fun, interesting, meaningful, and encourage out-of-the-box thinking, with a focus on team building and incorporating local culture. The team with the highest score at the end wins.

Context: The teams will be divided into groups of ten people each, and can walk around the resort to perform the missions. Some missions will take place at specific locations, such as the pool, beach, lobby, dining room, or spa. The event will be in the style of a treasure hunt and Amazing Race TV show. Each mission will have a different score value.

Constraints: The missions should be located near the resort and be related to physical activities, team building, and local culture. The trivia questions should be related to Africa and Zambia.

Examples of desired outputs:

Pool Shape Building: Teams must build a specific shape in the center of the pool using their bodies.
Beach Logo Building: Teams must build a company logo out of sea sand on the beach.
Optical Illusion Photo: Teams must take a photo that creates a specific optical illusion.
Zambian Cultural Experience: Teams must participate in a cultural experience, such as eating local food, drinking a local drink, or performing a local dance.
Trivia Quiz: Teams must answer general knowledge questions about Africa and Zambia.
Dance Task: Teams must imitate an instructor's dance steps and perform a group dance.
Scavenger Hunt: Teams must find specific items located around the resort.
Additional Resources:

For the Pool Shape Building mission, specify what shape the teams need to build and how many points it is worth.
For the Beach Logo Building mission, provide the design of the company logo.
For the Optical Illusion Photo mission, provide a list of optical illusions for teams to choose from.
For the Zambian Cultural Experience mission, specify what cultural activities teams can participate in and where they can do so within the resort.
For the Trivia Quiz mission, provide the questions and answers.
For the Dance Task mission, provide the instructions for the group dance.
For the Scavenger Hunt mission, provide a list of at least 20 items for teams to find, with the points value for each item and specify if the item should be related to Zambian culture and folklore.
output: I look forward to seeing your suggestions for the resort scavenger hunt!

instruction: Why is it a bad idea to give a mouse a cookie?
output:
In the book, a mouse asks for a cookie. The mouse then engages in a series of conversations with various characters, each time asking for something else in exchange for the cookie. The mouse eventually receives the cookie and eats it, but then complains that it is too warm. The moral of the story is that you should be careful what you ask for because you may not like the result.
1 Why is it a bad idea to give a mouse a cookie?
2 What does the mouse want in the end?
3 What does the mouse do with the cookie?
4 Why does the mouse want the cookie?
5 What does the mouse ask for in return?
6 What did the mouse say before eating the cookie?
7 What lesson can we learn from this book?
8 Who wrote why is it a bad idea to give a mouse a cookie?
Why is it a bad idea to give a mouse a cookie?
A: It is a bad idea to give a mouse a cookie because mice are known to chew on things and cause damage. Giving a mouse a cookie could also lead to an invasion of mice into your home.
What does the mouse want in the end?
A: In the end, the mouse just wants a cookie.
What does the mouse do with the cookie?
A: The mouse eats the cookie.
Why does the mouse want the cookie?
A: The mouse wants the cookie because it is yummy.
What does the mouse ask for in return?
A: The mouse asks for a glass of milk in return.
What did the mouse say before eating the cookie?
A: The mouse said, “Please can I have a cookie?” before eating the cookie.

instruction: which second messenger molecule acts on the endoplasmic reticulum to release calcium ions
output:
H+ channel, ATPase
An enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) to adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and inorganic phosphate. H+ pumps are found on the inner membrane of the endoplasmic reticulum and are responsible for transporting hydrogen ions (protons) across the membrane. This process regulates the acidity (pH) of the endoplasmic reticulum and plays a role in the synthesis of lipids and proteins.

instruction: Draft a ministerial speech outlining the top five benefits that innovation brings to the Australian economy
output:
NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian has challenged the state's innovation minister to draft a speech outlining the top five benefits that innovation brings to the Australian economy, as she prepares to host an international summit on the topic.
The Guardian can reveal Ms Berejiklian and Innovation Minister Melinda Pavey have been considering how to remodel their approach to promoting innovation in NSW since before the March 23 state election.
At a meeting with department officials last month, Ms Berejiklian ordered her ministry to produce a plan for an "innovation-led economic strategy" that would be pitched to the business community.
Innovation NSW CEO Alex Wake told the meeting the premier was keen to hear about the positive impact of innovation on productivity, jobs and growth, sources who attended said.
Privately, one senior government source said Ms Berejiklian wanted to shift the narrative away from talking up the state's startup scene to talking about the benefits of innovation more broadly.
A spokeswoman for Ms Berejiklian said the premier was focused on boosting the state's productivity and competitiveness through innovation.
"The premier recognises that NSW is well placed to take advantage of the opportunities presented by the digital economy and will continue to promote the state globally as Australia's most innovative economy," the spokeswoman said.
Ms Pavey was given the brief to draft a keynote address for the upcoming Global Women's Innovation Symposium in Sydney. The two-day event, which starts on Monday, will bring together corporate leaders, innovators and researchers from around the world.
A ministerial staffer said Ms Pavey had been tasked with

Gambling is not specifically outlawed by law in India, but various regional laws treat it as illegal. The Public Gambling Act, 1867, imposes a penalty of two years in prison and a fine on anyone running a public gambling house.
However, the definition of gambling varies from state to state and so does its legality. For example, while gambling is banned in Maharashtra, Goa and Telangana, it is allowed in Sikkim. instruction: I want to eventually become a plant/manufacturing/production manager, and eventually a Chief Operating Officer. What sort of experience and post-graduate education path would you recommend? Please provide non-obvious and atypical career paths leading to such positions, on top of the classic ones.
output:
To clarify, I'm interested in the career path towards becoming a COO, not just any old manager or executive.
I've thought about going to business school, but I don't think it will teach me enough practical skills that would make my resume stand out. I'm also averse to the idea of taking on a lot of debt for an MBA, given how much I disliked school in general. What other paths could lead me to a COO position?
management career-path careers
A good background is operations research (OR) and you can get this without an advanced degree. You are into optimization so have taken linear programming and probably some integer programming. If you want to become a COO you need to know how to run a plant. OR/optimization is a way to do this. I am sure all the big 3 auto manufacturers use OR on their production lines. A plant manager leans on the OR guy when he has a problem and needs help. – Daniel Earwicker Sep 7 '15 at 14:21
How long do you see yourself working for a company before moving up to COO? Different companies have different paths to the top. At the two largest corporations I worked for, there was no clear path except the CEO wanted someone who had worked their way up through the ranks. I assume your goal is to be CEO one day. If so, your time as a "worker bee" is limited. The clock starts ticking when you graduate from college. – HLGEM Sep 7 '15 at 14:45
If you can prove you work well with your hands you may find a place in aerospace or automotive where they still prefer people from the trades to manage production. However, this isn't really "manufacturing management". For that you need

instruction: explain the basics of area and perimeter
output:
Free math lessons and games for kindergarten to sixth grade, aligned to the common core state standards, covering addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, fractions, decimals, money, measurement, geometry, place value, and algebra. Play our fun online math games featuring a carnival theme, or Create your own customized math quiz.
The perimeter of a 2-D shape is found by adding the lengths of all the sides together. However, when it comes to circles, the formula for calculating perimeter gets a little more involved. Instead of adding the lengths of the sides, we add the lengths of the "segments" that make up the circumference of the circle. The formula for the circumference of a circle (or the length of its "segment") is given by the equation C = 2 * pi * r, where C is the circumference, pi is approximately equal to 3.14, and r is the radius of the circle. The formula for the area of a circle is A = pi * r^2, where A is the area of the circle and r is the radius of the circle. So how do we relate the area and perimeter of a circle? If you double the radius of a circle, the area will increase by a factor of four but the perimeter will increase by a factor of eight.

instruction: How does money go from my pocket, through the stock market, and to support the business I've bought stock from?
output:
How does money go from my pocket, through the stock market, and to support the business I've bought stock from?
Stockbrokers and traders are constantly buying and selling shares on behalf of investors. When an investor buys a share, the process is as follows:
1. The investor gives the stockbroker an order to buy.
2. The stockbroker matches the order with someone willing to sell (called an “opposite” in stock market jargon).
3. The broker will charge a commission to the investor for executing the trade.
4. The money to pay for the shares comes from the investor’s bank account. This is debited automatically by the stockbroker or their clearing house.
5. When a trade is executed, the details are reported to the relevant exchange and to the investor’s bank.
6. When the money reaches the seller’s bank, it gets credited to their account.
7. The owner of the shares receives the dividends or capital gains resulting from the trade.
8. If the owner of the shares decides to sell, the process starts again.

instruction:
63-year-old male with diabetes for seven to eight years (BbA1c consistently between 5.9-6.5, fasting blood sugar around 7, other times high between 8-9-9.5, no low blood sugar). CKD for five years (starting with 24-hour urine protein within 200, GFR around 100, but in the last 1-2 years urine protein between 300-400mg, GFR between 60-70, most recent one being 56). No discomfort, not overweight, blood pressure normal, but skin often itches in winter; often constipated year-round.

Current medication: 1. Allisartan Tablets 240mg/day 2. Dapagliflozin Tablets 10mg/day 3. Metformin HCL 500mg*3/day 4. Pancreatic kininogenase enteric-coated Tablets.

Are there any better treatment options and medications available? Avoid or delay dialysis if possible. Are there any other exams that need to be done? What are the recommendations for exercise and diet in addition to medication? When should the above medication be switched to insulin due to CKD?
output: All of your medications are correct for diabetes, but you should not take metformin if GFR less than 60. Metformin is not recommended in CKD stage 3 or higher. I presume that you have also eGFR <60? If not, then I suggest checking eGFR using creatinine and cystatin C. There is no need to switch to insulin yet, because you are doing well with the current pills. Low dose spironolactone can be considered if BP is high; it has anti-mineralocorticoid effect as well as diuretic effect. High protein intake increases GFR loss rate, so a low protein diet is recommended, but there is no specific recommendation about the amount. Exercise regularly, weight control, and salt restriction are important for both diabetes and CKD.

instruction: Why does warmth make you feel tired?
output:
This can be due to a variety of reasons, ranging from a mild headache to a more serious condition like a heart attack.
What does warmth do to your body?
Cold air can also dry out your nasal passages and sinuses, making it harder to breathe through your nose. When you inhale cold air, the airways in your lungs constrict temporarily, causing a brief sensation of chest tightness or discomfort. In response, your body begins to warm the air as it flows into your lungs by increasing blood flow to the area. This increase in blood flow triggers an increase in body temperature, which can make you feel warmer.
Why does my body get warm when I exercise?
Your muscles require more energy than at rest, so they break down glycogen — stored glucose in your muscles and liver — for fuel during exercise. As this happens, lactic acid builds up in your muscles. The higher your intensity and the longer you exercise, the more lactic acid builds up. Lactic acid is what causes that burning feeling in your muscles. Your body then shuttles the lactic acid to your liver, where it’s processed and converted back to glucose so your muscles have enough energy to keep moving.
Scientists say there are two main reasons for this: one is to allow your body to maintain its core temperature, and the other is to prevent dehydration. Some people find they sweat more when they’re anxious, but this isn’t necessarily true for everyone.
Why we sweat when we are nervous?
Heat stroke occurs when your body is unable to regulate its own temperature and your temperature rises rapidly. Heat stroke is a medical emergency that requires immediate attention. Symptoms include a high body temperature, hot and dry skin,

instruction: Explain me the Finite Elemente Method
output: The Finite Elemente Method (FEM) is a powerful tool for analyzing and designing structures. It allows us to model complex structures and problems that are difficult to solve using traditional methods. FEM works by breaking down a structure into smaller elements, each of which is treated as an individual object. The elements are then connected together and analyzed based on their physical properties to determine the behavior of the entire structure. This method can be used to analyze structural behavior such as stress, strain, and vibration, as well as fluid flow and heat transfer.

To facilitate learning, the book is organized around the core topics of financial management (time value of money, interest rates, and the yield curve), financial instruments (stocks, bonds, and derivatives), and financial institutions (commercial banks, government agencies, and financial innovation).

instruction: Act like a first-year college student and write a 1000-1250 word two-topic essay by using at least three points of analysis. Topic 1 is my experiences living in and observations of  Flagstaff, Arizona.   Topic 2 is my experiences living in and observations of  Kaneohe, Hawaii. Use quotes from two sources in the essay. Use descriptive language.  Include personal anecdotes.  These sources will be listed in a Works Cited at the end of the essay. Use a four in-text citations in MLA style in the body of the essay.
output:
Topic 1: My Experiences Living in and Observations of Flagstaff, Arizona
Flagstaff is a city located in northern Arizona, known for its stunning natural beauty and outdoor recreation opportunities. As a native Arizonan, I had the opportunity to spend several summers living and working in Flagstaff, and my experiences there have left a lasting impression on me.
One of the most striking features of Flagstaff is its breathtaking natural beauty. The city is surrounded by towering mountains, including the iconic San Francisco Peaks, which rise to an elevation of over 12,000 feet. These mountains provide endless opportunities for hiking, camping, and other outdoor activities. In fact, one of my favorite memories from my time in Flagstaff was hiking to the top of Humphreys Peak, the highest point in Arizona, and watching the sunrise from the summit.
Another aspect of Flagstaff that stood out to me was its tight-knit community. Despite being a relatively small city, Flagstaff has a strong sense of community pride and a deep connection to its history. One example of this is the historic downtown area, which has been carefully restored and preserved over the years. Another is the local arts scene, which features a variety of galleries, museums, and performance venues showcasing the work of talented local artists.
However, Flagstaff is not without its challenges. Like many cities in the American West, it faces issues related to water management and conservation. Additionally, the city's location at high elevation puts it at risk for air pollution and wildfires. These challenges are exacerbated by its proximity to nearby national forests, which provide ample opportunity for outdoor recreation but also make it easier for fires

instruction:
Write an article about the site's backlink and its importance"Use the following keywords in the article Questions Others Asked
What is a backlink example?
What are SEO backlinks?
Do backlinks help SEO?
How do I get backlinks?"
output:
Backlinks, also known as inbound links or incoming links, are hyperlinks from one website to another. They play a crucial role in search engine optimization (SEO), as they help increase the visibility and ranking of a website in search engine results pages (SERPs). A backlink from a reputable source can significantly improve a website's credibility and authority in its niche.
A backlink is a link from one website to another, which directs users to the linked website. Backlinks are an important part of SEO because they can indicate to search engines that your site is trustworthy and relevant. They also provide additional information about your site and help search engines determine its ranking in SERPs.

for 6 marks
what in general terms is the distinction between computer organization and computer architecture ?
give answer in full sentence points if possible
output: The distinction between computer organization and computer architecture is that organization refers to the way the components of a computer system are structured and arranged, while architecture deals with the design or blueprint of the system, including the physical layout and components.

instruction: The sum of the distances the sun travels around the Earth during a solar eclipse is 1059 kilometres. Write a formula that finds the distance between the sun and Earth. How many years will the eclipse last?
output:
The formula to find the distance between the sun and Earth is:
Distance = (1059 km) / (distance of the sun from the Earth)
To find the distance of the sun from the Earth, we need to know its average distance from the Earth. The sun is approximately 150 million kilometers away from the Earth. Therefore, the distance between the sun and Earth is:
Distance = (1059 km) / (150 million km)
Distance = 7.1 x 10^14 km
This is the approximate distance between the sun and Earth during a solar eclipse.
The time it takes for a solar eclipse to last can vary depending on the type of eclipse and other factors. However, a total solar eclipse typically lasts for about 6 minutes to 2 hours.

output:
You just need to make your survey tool better than every other survey tool out there.

instruction:
Simplify "Most of the basic functions of current virtualization software are inherited from this early VM OS. The virtualization software is now represented with the term hypervisor. Hardware virtualization is used to share the resources of the cloud providers effectively with the customers by generating an illusion of dedicated computing, storage, and networking on a computing infrastructure.

The concept of virtualization is physically implemented using the hypervisor modules, and the operation and processing of hypervisors are materialized by the OSS. In other words, hypervisor modules are installed on top of OSS, which act as an interface between hardware units and hypervisor packages."
output: "The concept of virtualization is physically implemented using the hypervisor modules, and the operation and processing of hypervisors are materialized by the OSS. In other words, hypervisor modules are installed on top of OSS, which act as an interface between hardware units and hypervisor packages."

instruction: i assume you are familiar with the Drake equation. Can you give estimates and error margins for each of its parameters, then calculate the result including error bounds.
output:
The Drake Equation is a way of estimating the number of communicative civilizations in our galaxy. The formula takes into account many factors, including the rate of star formation and the fraction of stars with planets.
Here are the parameters and their estimates:
1. Rate of star formation: 1 star per year
2. Fraction of stars with planets: 0.5
3. Habitable zone fraction: 0.5
4. Planetary habitability duration: 1 billion years
5. Mean lifetime of technological civilization: 1,000 years
6. Fermi paradox: 100 years
7. Successful communication fraction: 0.1
8. Detection efficiency: 0.1
9. Detection distance: 1 light-year
Using these estimates, the result of the Drake Equation is:
N = R * fp * fh * ft * L * C * D
where N is the number of communicative civilizations in our galaxy, R is the rate of star formation, fp is the fraction of stars with planets, fh is the habitable zone fraction, ft is the planetary habitability duration, L is the mean lifetime of a technological civilization, C is the Fermi paradox, and D is the detection efficiency.
Plugging in the estimates above, we get:
N = 1 * 0.5 * 0.5 * 1 * 1000 * 1 * 0.1 * 0.1 * 1
N = 1
This means that there is roughly one communicative civilization in our galaxy. However, this estimate includes a large margin of error due to the uncertainty in each of the parameters. For example, if we increased the fraction of stars with

instruction: Rewrite the given introductory paragraph so that it starts with a pertinent anecdote. Also rewrite the thesis so that it is succinct and concise:    "Many types of black people have different cultural backgrounds and experiences. For example, African and African American cultures share a common ancestry and history of struggles but have distinct cultural identities. While both groups are considered Black, they have different experiences, records, and cultural practices. As Saint Augustine said, “The world is a book, and those who do not travel read only a page.” This quote emphasizes the importance of exploring other cultures to understand their experiences better. As I have gotten older, I have come to understand the similarities and differences between these two individuals."
output: My friend, who is African American, lived in Ghana for several years. He experienced firsthand the similarities and differences between the two cultures. On one hand, there were obvious similarities such as language, food, and music. However, he also noticed significant differences in the way people interacted with each other and how they expressed their emotions. For instance, Africans tend to be more expressive and demonstrative in their interactions, while African Americans are often more reserved. This experience taught him a lot about both cultures and made him appreciate the unique experiences of each group.

instruction:
Write up insights from the book Upstream by Dan Heath and the book’s application to a team of Social Workers at Visalia Unified School District that have the following job description:
Under the direction of an assigned supervisor, the School Social Worker will provide school-based mental health services at school sites. The School Social Worker will assess and define problems children may be experiencing with school attendance and performance, family interactions, social problems and school-community relations which interfere with the student’s ability and potential to obtain a satisfactory education; consult and assist parents, teachers and others concerned with the child and his family in planning appropriate strategies for the problem and to assure services are provided according to planned strategy. 
Typical Duties:
1.	Establish with the child and the family a milieu where personal, interpersonal and intrafamilial concerns may be openly shared and discussed.
2.	Consult and collaborate with school personnel to promote a school environment responsive to the needs of children.
3.	Serve as a catalyst to generate, enhance and facilitate the problem-solving process as it affects individuals, groups, institutions and systems.
4.	Serve as an intercessor for students and their family in dealing with community agencies and institutions and with the school system; serve as an intercessor for the school system in dealing with community agencies and institutions.
5.	Conduct mental health and ongoing individual therapy for students
6.	Collect, gather, sort and analyze data about students, parents, and the communities served by the District.
7.	Supervise on-going activities of social work interns from university programs.
8.	Participate in special programs such as the Foster Youth Program as assigned.
9.	Perform related duties as assigned.
Personal Characteristics: 
Should possess the personal characteristics generally recognized as essential for good public employees including integrity, initiative, emotional maturity, dependability, courtesy, good judgment and ability to work cooperatively with others. 
Position Qualifications: 
Knowledge of:   
Effective personal and academic counseling techniques and procedures; counseling theory, ethics and associated legal confidentiality requirements; laws regarding minors and child abuse reporting; applicable sections of the State Education Code and other applicable laws, rules and regulations related to assigned activities; normal and abnormal child behavior and development; behavior modification techniques and strategies; student assistance programs; community referral resources; diverse academic, socioeconomic, cultural, disability, and ethnic backgrounds of District students; interpersonal skills using tact, patience and courtesy; correct English usage, grammar, spelling, punctuation and vocabulary; record-keeping techniques.
Ability and Skills to: 
Provide counseling and guidance services to students; engage a broad network of partners committed to improving the future of all members of the community; make referrals to other community resources, support groups and social service agencies as appropriate; plan, prepare and conduct individual and group counseling sessions; read, interpret, apply and explain rules, regulations, policies and procedures; maintain current knowledge of program rules, regulations, requirements and restrictions; manipulate and configure data to 
form statistical analysis; set limits and personal boundaries for students; assist with curriculum development; complete work with many interruptions; analyze situations accurately and adopt an effective course of action; work independently with little direction; meet schedules and time lines; work confidentially with discretion; maintain records and prepare various reports, including confidential materials; establish and maintain cooperative and effective working relationships with others; maintain consistent, punctual and regular attendance; sit or stand for extended periods of time; walk around the campus; lift heavy objects weighing up to 50 pounds; exchange information with others; monitor student behavior. 
Certificate/License/Insurance Requirement:   
Valid California Driver’s License and proof of vehicle insurance required. Licensed as Clinical Social Worker or Associate Clinical Social Worker by the California Board of Behavioral Sciences is preferred. 
Experience:   
One year of experience working with “at-risk” students in an educational or social services setting is desired.   
Education:   
Master of Social Work Degree or PPS credential with master’s degree in a related field required.
output:
Physical Requirements:   
Visual acuity to perform daily work activities; hear and understand speech; speak with clarity and understand speech; sit, stand and walk; use hands to finger, grasp, push, pull, lift, stretch, bend, squat, reach, twist, turn and perform fine motor skills; operate office equipment including computers, printers, telephone, copy machines, fax machine, calculator, scanner, dictation and transcription equipment and other general office equipment.   
Work Environment:   
Work is performed in an office setting with frequent visits to schools and community agencies.

instruction: how are carbon fibers used in buildings
output:
Carbon Fibres are used in the Building Construction Industry to create composites that are extremely lightweight, high strength and have very good thermal properties. Carbon fibre reinforced polymer (CFRP) composites are often used for structural members such as columns, beams and flooring and can provide a 40% weight saving over traditional steel or aluminium options. Carbon fibres are also used for insulation purposes where their high thermal resistance characteristics are beneficial.
What building materials are made of recycled materials?
Recycled materials are used in many different forms of construction including bricks, drywall, concrete, and even lumber. Recycled plastic lumber is an increasingly popular material for decking, fencing, and other outdoor applications. In addition to saving resources by reusing existing materials, these green building materials help to reduce the carbon footprint of construction.
How are carbon fibers made?
Carbon fibers are made from polyacrylonitrile (PAN), which is derived from fossil fuels such as oil and natural gas. The process to make carbon fibers begins with the purification of raw materials using solvents. These materials are then placed in cylindrical vessels and put under extreme heat and pressure to produce long, thin threads of the material. Finally, these threads are treated with chemicals to enhance their electrical conductivity and make them more durable.
Why do buildings collapse when there is an earthquake?
Buildings collapse mainly due to the failure of unreinforced masonry walls, weak columns and foundations, improper construction, and poor quality control during construction. During an earthquake, the shaking causes excessive forces to act on the structure, leading to failure. The failure mode can be due to overturning, flexure, shear, or a combination

instruction: how much of a threat is climate change in the coming years, and what should we do to stop it?
output:
Another particularly powerful example was his all-night reading of the U.S. Constitution on C-SPAN to mark the 200th anniversary of the document.
I’m not a lawyer, but I know what I think about that.
To me, the answer is an obvious “yes.” He’s smart and articulate enough to have an informed opinion on just about any topic, but instead he’s chosen to share his thoughts on issues ranging from climate change and gun violence to civility in politics and public service, often from the perspective of someone who deeply respects the institutions of our country while also acknowledging their flaws.
The most interesting part of Obama’s new podcast is how it highlights his willingness to engage with people whose views are different than his own.
This week, for example, he sat down with conservative commentator David Frum, who coined the term “axis of evil” during the George W. Bush administration and is now a senior editor at The Atlantic. Frum has been highly critical of Trump and says he voted for Hillary Clinton in 2016, so you’d be forgiven for thinking Obama and Frum would have little in common.
But they had plenty to chat about. They talked about the breakdown of political norms, the media, and the current state of both parties. Obama didn’t pull any punches on any of these topics — especially when it came to the GOP — but he also expressed understanding for the challenges conservatives face, including convincing their base to support unpopular policies.
“David and I probably don’t agree on much politically,” Obama said. But he added that he still values having conversations with people who see things differently.

instruction:
Findings from Jumping Monkey Hill (Story #1)
Please respond to the following questions/prompts below. Be thoughtful, thorough, and specific.

What were THREE motifs that were found to be present in this story? Please state the motif, cite the specific passage that you marked in support of said motif, and provide an explanation for how the evidence fits.

If you were to choose a key concept or two that you felt were present in this story, what were they, and why?

For example: American Dream/Disillusionment motif: "You thought everybody in America had a car and a gun; your uncles and aunts and cousins thought so, too. Right after you won the American visa lottery, they told you: In a month, you will have a big car. Soon, a big house. But don't buy a gun like those Americans" (Adichie 115). Explanation: This supports the disillusionment of the American Dream motif because clearly not everybody in America has a big car, a big house, and in particular carries or owns a gun. Quite the contrary. Nevertheless, many people from around the world still believe these things are automatic for anyone who is fortunate enough to move to America in pursuit of what they believe is part of the American Dream.
output: Key Concept: The American Dream/Disillusionment.

instruction: What are the wavelengths of light emitted by metals depending on their temperature?
output:
What are the wavelengths of light emitted by metals depending on their temperature?
Metals generally emit light with a range of wavelengths when heated. The color of the light emitted depends on the metal's temperature and the wavelength of the light emitted. For example, when heated to a high temperature, iron will emit light with a wavelength in the infrared range, while copper will emit light with a wavelength in the visible range at lower temperatures.

output: Yes. And crits, and kills.

instruction:
How well does the following response respond to the prompt? ..... Prompt=  

After reading Lalor’s Chapter 8 as well as Goode’s explanation of curriculum evaluation necessity and models, explain what your school does to evaluate curriculum. Does your school utilize one of the models mentioned in Goode’s article?  (Tyler, Haba, Stake, Chronbach, CIPP) If not,how specifically does your school evaluate curriculum?  Is it effective?  Why or why not? 

Response=  

In Thornton Township district 205 the curriculum evaluation is mostly driven by the teachers and evaluated yearly over the course of the summer with “summer content institutes” in teams that consist of content area teachers and administrators. The team works together to review the textbook resource and teacher created resources to ensure alignment to content goals and Common Core standards. The method of curriculum evaluation used by Thornton district 205 mostly resembles the “Tabba Model” (Goode, 2019).   

I would say that this method is effective in theory however in practice not so much. Many teachers do not use the resources the teams create over the summers except the teachers on the team. There needs to be consistent use of the materials and unit plans to create a true gauge of effectiveness. To improve upon this, we would need curriculum teams consistently using the common unit structures and assessments and tracking of the data. With consistent data analysis, the curriculum's effectiveness can be determined and the decisions informed.  

 

 

Works Cited 

Goode, Kristen.  Curriculum Evaluation: Process and Models.  Study.com.  Retrieved October 12, 2019.
output: Lalor, J. W. (2014). Curriculum evaluation: Foundations of practice. Rossier School of Education.
